ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This was the first time that I have taken a Yale math course and felt like the learning experience was *worse* than it would have been if I were teaching myself. I suppose I learned a lot about the most effective ways to read a math textbook? But that's really not what I was looking for from this course. I do feel as if I have a rudimentary understanding of Galois theory, but without covering any of the applications that make Galois theory beautiful and important, it feels extremely unmotivated. The majority of the course felt like definition shuffling.
Galois theory and some other relevant theorems in field theory.
We learned how to approach fields and Galois theory, including many fascinating results such as proving that degree 5 polynomials do not have a general solution formula.
Learned Galois Theory basics
Galois theory (up to Fundamental Theorem of Galois theory), proofs
We learned a lot about certain behaviors of fields and relating their properties to polynomials.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strengths of this course were very few. In general, lectures felt disorganized and unprepared. No explanation was given about why we were interested in the various results. In general, the content of the course was presented in a very circular manner: A is important because it allows us to understand B, and B is important because it tells us about A. Prof. Qiu only taught "Galois theory" in the very narrowest sense, and never connected the language of Galois theory to any interesting questions outside of this narrow scope. Beyond the content of the lectures, the actual presentation was extremely difficult to follow. Prof. Qiu would present on a rather small screen, and was constantly scrolling up and down without giving enough time to take thorough notes. Fortunately, I suppose, the proofs in the textbook were typically easier to understand than Prof. Qiu's presentation, so I took notes on the textbook instead of on the lecture. That said, the textbook we used was *still* a pretty bad one, in my opinion (we used "Fields and Galois Theory" by Patrick Morandi). The material of the entire semester was crammed into the first 60 or so pages of the textbook, in an extremely dense format. In my opinion, many of the proofs in the text were also lacking in rigour--not checking things like well-definedness or uniqueness of various constructions. The problem sets were also a mess. This was the first time that I have felt like the problem sets in a math course did *nothing* to improve understanding. The problems were either (a) definition shuffling, (b) results that were already proven in the textbook or in lecture, or (c) artificially complicated scenarios that only obfuscated a rather straightforward idea. We might have had two or three useful homework problems, but they were few and far between.

Strength: Some of the examples Professor Qiu gave were really interesting and facilitated my learning. Also Professor Qiu is an ethusiastic instructor, always willing to take advice from students to improve his teaching, and put efforts to best help the student's learning experience.
Weakness: Sometimes it is hard to follow Professor's class note in live sessions. Might be better when switching back to in-person learning.
The class is good at teaching the material, but sometimes the professor is hard to understand and the course moves pretty fast.

The lectures were very haphazard and confusing and often mistakes were made (which happens, but the lecture style was just generally very confusing and this didnt make it any easier). The course could be improved with pre prepared notes perhaps? Or maybe it will simply be easier in person when the effects of scrolling a virtual screen are not important.

Strengths: Prof. Qiu was so knowledgeable, clearly cared about the students, and constantly strived to improve the learning experience. Lectures were good for the most part. Weaknesses: Lectures were sometimes disorganized and pace was either too fast or too slow.
The professor was really engaged and it made the class very enjoyable. There plenty of cool results and the office hours and other extra help were accessible.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Prof. Qiu presented his lectures using what appeared to be the OneNote app on his iPad. The display was extremely buggy, cutting out frequently and jumping around the screen, making it very difficult to follow the proofs that he was writing.
Virtual lectures went very smoothly. Office hours were very accessible as well.
Office hours on varied days and times helped to make extra help more accessible.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I have two answers for this question. Certainly, I recommend that every math student take Galois Theory. From my own exploration, it is a beautiful subject, with fascinating connections to various classical problems in math: compass-and-straightedge constructions, solving polynomials by radicals, identifying transcendental numbers. This is some seriously cool stuff, and you'd be crazy to *not* want to learn it.

That said, I cannot recommend that anybody take this course with Prof. Qiu. I really hate to say it, because he seems to be a really nice guy, and he genuinely seems to be trying his best to teach this course well. Unfortunately, it just doesn't work. I will copy some of the problems I had from my "Strengths and Weaknesses" response below. TLDR: we never talked about how Galois theory relates to these classic mathematical questions, and everything we did was totally unmotivated.

In general, lectures felt disorganized and unprepared. No explanation was given about why we were interested in the various results. In general, the content of the course was presented in a very circular manner: A is important because it allows us to understand B, and B is important because it tells us about A. Prof. Qiu only taught "Galois theory" in the very narrowest sense, and never connected the language of Galois theory to any interesting questions outside of this narrow scope. Beyond the content of the lectures, the actual presentation was extremely difficult to follow. Prof. Qiu would present on a rather small screen, and was constantly scrolling up and down without giving enough time to take thorough notes. Fortunately, I suppose, the proofs in the textbook were typically easier to understand than Prof. Qiu's presentation, so I took notes on the textbook instead of on the lecture. That said, the textbook we used was *still* a pretty bad one, in my opinion (we used "Fields and Galois Theory" by Patrick Morandi). The material of the entire semester was crammed into the first 60 or so pages of the textbook, in an extremely dense format. In my opinion, many of the proofs in the text were also lacking in rigour--not checking things like well-definedness or uniqueness of various constructions. The problem sets were also a mess. This was the first time that I have felt like the problem sets in a math course did *nothing* to improve understanding. The problems were either (a) definition shuffling, (b) results that were already proven in the textbook or in lecture, or (c) artificially complicated scenarios that only obfuscated a rather straightforward idea. We might have had two or three useful homework problems, but they were few and far between.
Yes I would reccomend if he or she feels comfortable and familiar with the materials in MATH 350 and want to learn more about field theory.
I 100% recommend taking Galois Theory. It is a beautiful subject, and is definitely worthwhile to appreciate and admire. Make sure to read about the story of Evariste Galois before taking!
Only if they are majoring in mathematics.
I would, if math is something you really want to get into.

I would not recommend this to a friend. Perhaps if the content was structured more about how to actually use the results of Galois theory (which were mostly left to students doing group projects) the class would be more digestible? I think in general the style of the lectures made it difficult to learn.

Yes, if you enjoy math and abstract algebra. There are many applications of Galois theory, it turns out, in other branches of math (differential equations, topology), so Galois theory is very important for higher algebra. 370 was not as intense as 350 but you still have to be diligent because the material in 370 is already pretty advanced.
Yes. This course if full of interesting and surprising results.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The lecture was live, but recorded, so students had the option of attending live or watching the recordings asynchronously.
None
Zoom office hours
